Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: INSTANCES: Incorporating Computational Scientific Thinking Advances into Education & Science Courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computational Science combines computer simulations and knowledge from a science discipline to solve complex problems. While a decade ago computational science was rare and found mainly in research programs, today it is recommended even for K-12 education as an effective pedagogy for teaching science, math and computer science in context. However, science and math teachers are often not prepared well for their work with computers in K-12 classrooms. They may not be able to explain what is occurring within the computer applications used by their students. The investigators are developing a new course for students who plan to be K-12 teachers, called Computational Scientific Thinking and Modeling for Teachers. The course is designed to provide practical computation integrated into the scientific problem-solving paradigm and a contextual understanding of the important of computation. This will lead to better prepared teachers, to better informed students and to broader participation in computing.

The project represents a multi-institution collaboration among a computational physics educator, a science and math educator, an education foundation, a computational biologist and two community college science teachers. Course materials include online content and a collection of video-based modules. Student learning outcomes are being assessed and the results are being disseminated at national meetings for science and math teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INSTANCES: Incorporating Computational Scientific Thinking Advances into Education & Science Courses developed several exemplary models and simulations, with Shodor's work focusing on physics and community college level courses.  The examples used were demonstrated and tested in classroom settings showing how to build understanding through a modeling first approach, as contrasted with a "teaching to program first" approach.  Students Were given working models that they could vary both parameters and the models themselves; they demonstrated the ability to vary parameters in a model to achieve a desired outcome or to investigate variation and change and compared it to algebraic manipulation or calculus-based integration to understand constant systems, or systems under linear, quadratic, and exponential forces.  Examples developed included general physics in kinetics and dynamics, heat diffusion, and electric fields, randomness, projectiles with drag.  The goal has been to demostrate the ability to learn science through computational thinking in a dynamic, visual, and interactive mode.  Other models were developed in biology, chemistry, and general computational thinking showing how the basic models are similar across the sciences.  Once developed and tested in the classroom, the examples have been incorporated into the Computational Science Education Reference Desk, a Pathway portal of the National Science Digital Libary, and used in Shodor's workshops through its National Computational Science Institute for use by other educators.  The models developed, both at Linn-Benton and Shodor, have been used in undergraduate classes for majors, in summer workshops for undergraduate faculty, and in after-school and summer workshops for pre-college students. In addition, a new course was developed at Linn-Benton Community College in computational thinking and now serves as a prerequisite for physics students who had not taken high school physics.  Dissemination through NSDL has been promoted at state and national AAPT meetings.
